articles.title: EPHEMERIS
articles.summary: This document, titled "EPHEMERIS," presents an astronomical chart for April, likely related to the SJAA organization. The chart displays celestial coordinates, time markers, and the path of Polaris across centuries, from 1700 to 2200, serving as a long-term reference. It details the positions of stars and celestial poles over time, likely aiding in astronomical observation or planning.

articles.title: CALENDAR
articles.summary: This document is a calendar of astronomical and club-related events scheduled for April and May. It details various star-parties, board and general membership meetings, an Astronomy Day, and an auction. Noteworthy events include an occultation of Jupiter, a talk on astrophotography, and the Riverside Telescope Makers Convention.

articles.title: WOULD YOU LIKE MORE PUBLIC EVENTS?
articles.summary: This document, titled 'WOULD YOU LIKE MORE PUBLIC EVENTS?', primarily serves as the masthead and contact information for EPHEMERIS, the monthly publication of the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines submission guidelines for contributions, welcomes astronomical photos, and lists the association's key officers and board of directors with their contact details.

articles.title: BY D. MEDLOCK
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is preparing for two major events: National Astronomy Day on April 23rd, where volunteers are sought to engage the public with telescopes, and their annual auction on April 30th, requiring assistance with registration, item handling, and refreshments. The article also notes the availability of the club's 12" Dobson telescope for member borrowing after May 7th and announces a cartoon caption contest. These activities highlight the club's active community engagement and member resources.

articles.title: JUPITER OCCULTATION
articles.summary: The article details an occultation of Jupiter by the waning gibbous moon set to occur on the morning of April 2. Observers south of the California-Oregon-Nevada border will witness a total occultation, with immersion at 4:43 am and emersion at 5:29 am. It also briefly mentions an unobservable daylight occultation of Mars on July 9 and a more favorable twilight occultation of Saturn on December 29.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This 'Comet Comments' article reports on recent comet activity, including a newly discovered faint comet and another brightening comet expected to reach magnitude 9.5 in July, with included positions. It also details Periodic Comet Bowell-Skiff (1983c), discovered on a photograph by Edward Bowell and Brian Skiff, describing its current fading status and orbital characteristics. Additionally, it mentions a historical note on the first comet discovered by a Canadian observer.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k)
articles.summary: This article presents an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Kopff (1982k) covering March through May 1983, including its right ascension, declination, and estimated magnitude. It notes the comet is slowly approaching both Earth and the Sun, while appearing almost stationary in the constellation Libra. The data provided is sourced from IAU Circular 3779.

articles.title: PAST DISCOVERIES
articles.summary: Comet Meier (1978r) was discovered by Rolf Meier of Ottawa, Canada, on April 26, 1978, using a 16-inch reflector after 50 hours of searching over three years. Initially at magnitude 10.4 in the constellation Lynx, it was located approximately 3.0 AU from both the Sun and Earth. The comet slowly brightened and became a significant celestial object before gradually fading over a year after its discovery.

articles.title: BY JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: This article reports on recent observations of a celestial 'Spot,' likely the Great Red Spot, noting that poor weather hindered observations on the west coast. Gerry Rattley in Arizona successfully observed it on March 9, describing its appearance and reporting an earlier-than-predicted transit time, advising observers to start early. The document concludes with a detailed table of predicted Great Red Spot meridian transit times for April and May.

articles.title: ANNOUNCEMENTS
articles.summary: This announcement details significant changes to membership options and renewal pricing for the 83/84 period. New options include a standard membership with Sky and Telescope for $21.00, a junior membership (under 12) including Sky and Telescope for $15.00, and a membership-only option for $8.00.

articles.title: SJAA MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION/RENEWAL
articles.summary: This document is an application and renewal form for membership with the SJAA organization. It requests personal contact information and an area of interest from applicants, offering various membership options, including a standard membership with or without a Sky & Telescope subscription, and a junior membership, each with specified annual fees.

articles.title: BY DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz compares a 6-inch refractor with a 10-inch reflector telescope, evaluating their performance across various observing conditions. The 6-inch refractor provided sharper images and better contrast, especially at high magnifications and for brighter objects. Conversely, the 10-inch reflector excelled at observing fainter deep-sky objects due to its superior light-gathering capability, a difference attributed to objective diameter, focal ratio, light loss, and secondary mirror obstruction.

articles.title: BY BOB FINGERHUT
articles.summary: The Ventura County Astronomical Society and Orange County Astronomers co-sponsored a one-day astrophotographic seminar on March 5th, attended by four S.gda members including the author. Presentations covered diverse topics such as tri-color photography, film development, new films, solar eclipse and comet photography, filters, and light pollution, with Reverend Ronald Royer giving a notable color tour of the Milky Way. The event proved inspiring, leaving attendees with numerous new ideas for astrophotography.

articles.title: ADDS
articles.summary: This document features two classified advertisements. Vince Huggins is selling a CAVE 6" F/4 RFT telescope, described as being in very good, like-new condition, for the best offer over $125. Additionally, Lou Lassabatere is seeking good, used equipment for a weather station, specifically mentioning barometers and cupwheels.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL SOCIETY OF THE PACIFIC
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific (ASP) and Western Amateur Astronomers (WAA) are co-sponsoring a week-long astronomical meeting in Hawaii from June 19-25, 1983, featuring a symposium on spectroscopy, amateur papers, a teachers' workshop, observatory tours, and non-technical lectures. Additionally, the document promotes upcoming KGO-FM radio programs in April 1983, covering an astronomy Q&A with Andrew Fraknoi and a discussion on extraterrestrial impact and dinosaur extinction with Helen Michel.

articles.title: MEETING LOCATION:
articles.summary: This document outlines four different meal and lodging plans for attendees of a meeting or conference, primarily focusing on camping options with varying meal inclusions and prices. It also provides information on an alternative lodging option at the Weldon Resort Motel and mentions key dates for attendance and a deadline.

articles.title: HOW TO REACH US:
articles.summary: This document provides initial instructions for reaching a location, noting that driving directions will be on the next page. It mentions the availability of telescopes and lodging, advises visitors to watch out for snakes, and suggests bringing binoculars for an event. The text also briefly touches upon meal options and formal rules.

articles.title: ARRIVAL TIMES:
articles.summary: The conference grounds are scheduled to open at 1:00 pm on Saturday, June 20. Attendees are advised against early arrival to ensure they are properly registered before gaining access, and to avoid issues with the registration process.

articles.title: PICNIC:
articles.summary: This document, titled "PICNIC," is a highly fragmented and disorganized collection of contact information for various lodging options (motels, inns, lodges, campgrounds) located in Big Bear Lake and Big Bear City, California. It vaguely mentions reserving accommodations and a meal plan, but provides no coherent details about the nature or purpose of the "PICNIC" event itself.

articles.title: REPLY BLANKS:
articles.summary: This document, titled 'REPLY BLANKS,' is a poorly structured communication that outlines deadlines for meetings and, more clearly, issues a 'SPECIAL' request for abstracts or papers. Submissions should detail research, experiments, or telescope applications, including title, description, and estimated equipment, with presentations limited to 30 minutes. The overall context suggests an event or call for proposals related to scientific research and telescope operations.

articles.title: HOTCHKILLING NO ___
articles.summary: This document serves as a registration form and information guide for an event hosted by the Riverside Telescope Makers Conference, an annual gathering for astronomy enthusiasts. It outlines various registration options, including costs for meals, lodging, and camping, along with detailed directions to the conference site in the Riverside/Big Bear area. The conference will feature souvenir exhibits related to telescopes and photography and is planned to proceed regardless of weather conditions.

articles.title: LOCAL ASTRONOMY SITES
articles.summary: This document features a hand-drawn map detailing local astronomy sites primarily in the San Francisco Bay Area and surrounding regions of California. It highlights key locations such as Lick Observatory and Fremont Peak State Park, along with various towns, roads, and geographical features, serving as a navigational guide for stargazers.

articles.title: TIME VALUE â€” DATED
articles.summary: This document presents boilerplate mailing information, including the address for "SILVA - PREMIERS" located at 3509 Calico Ave, San Jose, CA 95124, and details regarding U.S. postage paid. It appears to be a header or footer for a mailed item, rather than an article with substantive content.
